artifact_name: model; knife; tongs; axe; chisel; tool/implement; foundation-deposit
Description: Six copper model tools: knife, tongs, axe-head, two chisels and thin instrument with serrated end; chisels chased with prenomen and epithets of Thutmosis III. The axe-head is much damaged, originally of symmetrical form with incurved sides. Most of the butt and much of one side are lost through corrosion. When intact the butt was bent over in the form of a roughly cylindrical socket. Chased on one face is a hieroglyphic inscription.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Osiris-Khentimentu (Abydos), foundation deposit
Curator's comments: The axe is additional to the two published by Petrie in 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), 30-1, pl. LXI, 5. It presumably belongs to one of the several other foundation deposits of Tuthmosis III mentioned by Petrie, op. cit. II, 18 and 21, pl. LXIII, but it is nowhere specifically identified in the publication. On these deposits see further Kemp, 'Mitteilungen der Deutschen Archäologischen Instituts Abteilung Kairo' 23 (Wiesbaden, 1968), 143; and J. Morris Weinstein, 'Foundation Deposits in Ancient Egypt' (Pennsylvania, 1973 [Dissertation]), 176-8.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (120)
